(44) 267.24th May, 1944.WAR CABINET.AIR OPERATIONS IN ENEMY-OCCUPIED TERRITORY.Note by the Secretary.BY direction of the Prime Minister, the annexed correspondence with the deputy Supreme Commander, Allied Expeditionary Force, is circulated for theinformation of the War Cabinet and Defence Committee.(Signed) E. E. BRIDGES.Offices of the War Cabinet, S. W. 1, ,24th May, 1944.Minute from the Prime Minister, dated 21st May, 1944.Air Chief Marshal Tedder.Railroad Bombing.How does your score stand now, and are you keeping well within the limitsyou mentioned ?*(Intld.) W. S. C.21.5.44.* This refers to a conclusion of a meeting of the Defence Committee - held on the3rd May, 1944'(d.o. (44) 9th Meeting, Conclusion (b) (i)), at which the Deputy supreme commander was invited to review the plan for attacks on railway centres in the light of thevarious discussions on the matter and with a view to ensuring that the number of civilianskilled up to d day did not exceed 10,000.Minute from Air -Chief Marshal Tedder, dated 23rd May, 1944.Prime Minister.Railway Bombing.You asked me in your Minute 592/4 of the 21st May how the score standsnow. You will appreciate that it is very difficult to get a really reliable estimate,but the information available to us indicates that it is well within the limits I mentioned.[27516] 2. According to Axis reports of civilian casualties to date, the score boardreads as follows : Axis Reported Credit BalanceKilled. Remaining.6,062 3,938These figures show that casualties inflicted, as judged by the enemy, are some40 percent, less than our estimates.3. Against these civilian casualties the Transportation Plan already showsconsiderable profits. Some 2,450 Germans have been killed, including 285 of the300 railway specialists despatched from Germany to repair Creil. One reportsays that at Clignancourt 400' Germans celebrating Hitler's birthday are still under the ruins. Another valuable dividend has been the considerable number ofammunition trains that have been blown up. For the overall effect on Germany'sstrategic plans, we have evidence that the interruption of supply and of troop movements has already been effectively achieved by the Allies.(Signed) A. TEDDER. .23.5.44.
